newsitem.title: USA: Apple employees "in the money" from stock options.
newsitem.headline: Apple employees "in the money" from stock options.

text.p: Millions of Macintosh purists may not be happy about the pact Apple Computer Inc. made with nemesis Microsoft Corp., but lots of Apple employees certainly are.

News of Microsoft's $150 million investment in Apple has sent Apple's stock soaring 52 percent in two days. That makes the stock options some Apple employees receive as part of their compensation extremely valuable for now.
Apple shares surged from $19.75 Tuesday, before the Microsoft investment announcement, to close at $29.188 Thursday on Nasdaq.

"I am doing great -- getting better. I'm selling all my Apple stock," said Dale Fuller, the former head of Apple's Powerbook division. "Whoohoo!" he shouted into his cellular phone as he drove down the freeway.
Options allow employees to buy their company's stock at a discount to the market price. Silicon Valley companies rely heavily on options to pay their employees.

In Apple's case, key employees were given stock options in July with an "exercise price" of $13.25 a share. One thousand of those options had a paper value of $16,750 Thursday as Apple stock hit $30 a share. Those same options were nearly worthless a month ago, when Apple's stock lingered at about $14.

There's one catch: Employees have to wait at least a year from this past July to cash the options in. Depending on various terms, they can only cash them in batches stretched over three to five years.
